newsitem.title: BRAZIL: COCOA--Brazil producers pin hopes on rain plane.
newsitem.headline: COCOA--Brazil producers pin hopes on rain plane.

text.p: Concern over dry weather in Brazil's main cocoa-growing region of Bahia has become so acute that sector representatives have hired an airplane which will try and provoke rainfall, a producer official said.
"We have contracted an airplane from the Fundacao Cearense de Meteorologia e Recursos Hidricos," said Wallace Setenta, president of the National Cocoa Producers Council (CNPC).
"The airplane flies until it identifies the right kind of clouds and then it applies chemical products to try and make it rain," he added.
The method was last used by producers in 1972, he said.
"It is very difficult to gauge the results but it is an attempt to do something," he said.
Widespread rains in the region last fell in the middle of December and since then there has been only scattered showers.
Already producers are talking about the possibility of a 30 percent fall in last year's 1.5 million 60-kg bag midcrop which runs from May to September.
"At the moment, we are looking at around one million bags possibly," Setenta said.
The rain-making plane arrived in the region today and will begin work tomorrow, Setenta said.
It has been contracted for a flying-time of 30 hours at a cost of 35,000 reais ($33,650).

The cost is being borne by all areas of the cocoa sector, including growers' associations, cocoa industries and exporters, with the largest contribution coming from the Bahia state government, Setenta said.
-- Caroline Bulloch, Rio de Janeiro newsroom, 5521 5074151
